# List of wars involving Moldova

This is a list of conflicts involving Moldova.
:
:
:
*e.g. result unknown or indecisive/inconclusive, result of internal conflict inside Moldova, status quo ante bellum, or a treaty or peace without a clear result.
Medieval wars of Moldavia (1359–1512)
Below is a list of significant military conflicts involving Moldavia during the medieval period.
{| class="wikitable"
|+ List of Medieval Wars involving Moldavia
! Year !! Conflict/Battle !! Combatant 1 !! Combatant 2 !! Result
|-
| 1359 || Founding of Moldavia ||  Principality of Moldavia ||  Kingdom of Hungary || style="background:#D4F7D4" |Victory
*Moldavia establishes itself as an independent principality.
|-
| 1387 || Incorporation into Poland ||  Principality of Moldavia ||  Kingdom of Poland ||style="background:#E6EAFF" |Treaty
*Moldavia becomes a vassal of Poland.
|-
| 1399 || Battle of the Vorskla River ||  Grand Duchy of Lithuania Kingdom of Poland  Principality of Moldavia Wallachia Principality of Kiev Teutonic Order  ||  Golden HordeSupport by: Principality of Moscow || style="background:#FFDDDD" |Defeat
*The Lithuanian forces suffered a significant defeat against the Golden Horde, marking a setback for their influence in the region.
|-
| 1410 || Siege of Marienburg ||  Principality of Moldavia  Kingdom of Poland Grand Duchy of Lithuania ||  State of the Teutonic Order ||style="background:#FFDDDD" |Defeat
*Despite efforts, Moldavian and allied forces were unable to capture Marienburg, maintaining the Teutonic Order's control.
|-
| 1420 || Siege of Khillia and White fortresses ||  Principality of Moldavia Kingdom of Poland ||  Ottoman Empire || style="background:#D4F7D4" |Victory
*Ottoman failure to capture Khillia and White fortresses
|-
| 1462 || Battle of Chilia ||  Principality of Moldavia ||  Wallachia   Ottoman Empire || style="background:#FFDDDD" |Defeat
*Loss leads to increased Ottoman influence.
|-
| 1467 || Battle of Baia  ||  Principality of Moldavia ||  Kingdom of Hungary || style="background:#D4F7D4" |Victory
*This victory allowed Moldavia to recapture territories and affirm its independence against Hungary.
|-
| 1470 || Battle of Lipnic ||  Principality of Moldavia ||  Golden Horde || style="background:#D4F7D4" |Victory
*Decisive victory by Stephen the Great, leading to significant Tatar losses and strengthened Moldavian borders.
|-
| 1473 || Siege of Dâmbovița Fortress ||  Principality of Moldavia ||  Wallachia || style="background:#D4F7D4" |Victory
*Wallachian voivode ran away from the fortress, leaving his flags, treasury, and family
|-
| 1475 || Battle of Vaslui ||  Principality of Moldavia Kingdom of Hungary Kingdom of Poland ||  Ottoman Empire || style="background:#D4F7D4" |Victory
*Decisive defeat of the Ottomans, maintaining independence.
|-
| 1476 || Battle of Valea Albă ||  Principality of Moldavia Kingdom of Hungary Grand Duchy of Lithuania ||  Ottoman Empire || style="background:#FFDDDD" |Defeat
*Despite heavy Ottoman losses, Moldavia was forced to retreat.
|-
| 1476 || Siege of Neamț Citadel ||  Principality of Moldavia ||  Ottoman Empire || style="background:#D4F7D4" |Victory
*The Moldavian garrison successfully repelled the siege, forcing the Ottomans to withdraw.
|-
| 1485 || Battle of Cătlăbuga ||  Principality of Moldavia ||  Ottoman Empire || style="background:#D4F7D4" |Victory
*Further assertion of Moldavian sovereignty.
|-
| 1487 || Battle of Valea Albă ||  Principality of Moldavia ||  Ottoman Empire || style="background:#FFDDDD" |Defeat
*Moldavia loses to the Ottomans, eventually becoming a tributary state.
|-
| 1497 || Battle of the Cosmin Forest ||  Principality of Moldavia ||  Kingdom of Poland || style="background:#D4F7D4" |Victory
*saw Moldavia, under Stephen the Great, defeat Polish forces led by King John I Albert. Moldavia's strategic ambush forced Poland to abandon its claim, preserving Moldavia’s independence
|-
| 1531 || Battle of Obertyn ||  Principality of Moldavia ||  Kingdom of Poland || style="background:#FFDDDD" |Defeat
*Obertyn in Pokutia, Ukraine.
|-
| 1600 || Battle of Mirăslău ||  Principality of Moldavia Wallachia Transylvania ||  Kingdom of Hungary ||style="background:#FFDDDD" |Defeat
*Loss that challenges the unity of Moldavia and Wallachia and Transylvania.
|}
Ottoman Period (1512–1812)
Below is a list of significant military conflicts involving Moldavia during the Ottoman period.
{| class="wikitable"
|+ List of Wars involving Moldavia during the Ottoman period
! Year !! Conflict/Battle !! Combatant 1 !! Combatant 2 !! Result
|-
| 1538 || Conquest of Moldavia by the Ottoman Empire ||  Principality of Moldavia ||  Ottoman Empire || style="background-color:#FFDDDD;"|Defeat: Moldavia officially becomes a vassal state of the Ottoman Empire.
|-
| 1572 || Battle of Fântâna Albă ||  Principality of Moldavia ||  Ottoman Empire || style="background-color:#FFDDDD;"|Defeat: Another defeat leading to increased Ottoman dominance.
|-
| 1574 || Battle of Jiliște ||  Principality of Moldavia, ||  Ottoman Empire, Wallachia || style="background-color:#D4F7D4;"|Victory: Moldova and the Cossacks win.
|-
| 1595 || Battle of Cecora (1595) ||  Principality of Moldavia,  Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth ||  Ottoman Empire || style="background-color:#D4F7D4;"|Victory: Peace and the withdrawal of the Turks from Moldavia
|-
| 1595 || Battle of Giurgiu ||  Principality of Moldavia,  Principality of Wallachia,  Principality of Transylvania ||  Ottoman Empire || style="background-color:#D4F7D4;"|Victory: Decisive victory for Moldavia, Wallachia, and allies, significantly weakening Ottoman control.
|-
| 1595 || Battle of Suceava ||  Principality of Moldavia, Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth ||  Ottoman Empire, Principality of Transylvania || style="background-color:#D4F7D4;"|Victory: Moldova and Polish-Lithuanian forces under the command of Jan Potocki defeated the Transylvanian forces commanded by Ştefan Răzvan.
|-
| 1620 || Battle of Cecora (1620) ||  Principality of Moldavia,  Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth ||  Ottoman Empire || style="background-color:#FFDDDD;"|Defeat: A setback for Moldavia's alliances with Poland.
|-
| 1653 || Battle of Finta ||  Principality of Moldavia,  ||  Wallachia,  Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth || style="background-color:#FFDDDD;"|Defeat: Losses affecting Moldavia's territorial integrity.
|-
| 1683 || Battle of Vienna (participation) ||  Principality of Moldavia (Allies) ||  Ottoman Empire || style="background-color:#E6EAFF;"|Neutral: Allied forces repel the Ottomans in Europe.
|-
| 1683 || Battle of Chițcani (1683) ||  Principality of Moldavia,  Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth,  ||  Ottoman Empire, Budjak Horde|| style="background-color:#D4F7D4;"|Victory: This battle helped to reinforce Moldavia's position and assert its autonomy within the region during the Ottoman period.
|-
| 1711 || Pruth River Campaign ||  Principality of Moldavia, ,  Tsardom of Russia ||  Ottoman Empire || style="background-color:#FFDDDD;"|Defeat: Results in Moldavia's temporary loss of autonomy.
|-
| 1739 || Battle of Stavchany ||  Principality of Moldavia,  Russian Empire ||  Ottoman Empire || style="background-color:#D4F7D4;"|Victory: Restores some autonomy for Moldavia.
|-
| 1769 || Battle of Cahul ||  Principality of Moldavia,  Russian Empire ||  Ottoman Empire || style="background-color:#D4F7D4;"|Victory: Significant victory aiding Moldavia's standing against the Ottomans.
|-
| 1775 || Occupation of Bukovina ||  Principality of Moldavia ||  Habsburg Monarchy || style="background-color:#FFDDDD;"|Defeat: Bukovina is ceded to the Habsburg Monarchy.
|-
| 1788 || Siege of Khotyn (1788) ||  Principality of Moldavia,  Russian Empire ||  Ottoman Empire || style="background-color:#D4F7D4;"|Victory: Strengthens Moldavia's position in negotiations with the Ottomans.
|-
| 1792 || Treaty of Jassy ||  Principality of Moldavia ||  Ottoman Empire || style="background-color:#E6EAFF;"|Treaty: Defines new borders with Russia; Moldavia remains under Ottoman control.
|-
| 1812 || Treaty of Bucharest (1812) ||  Principality of Moldavia ||  Russian Empire || style="background-color:#FFDDDD;"|Defeat: Eastern Moldavia (Bessarabia) ceded to the Russian Empire.
|}
